column13: EUR 50/t packed glass=EUR45000/kt melt. Normalised to the 0.262 kt CO2 emitted/kt melt by base furnace plus 0.028 for post-melting process: 45000/.268/1.e6=0.17 MEUR/kt CO2 captured. 75% avoided, assumed 30% energy penalty of NG furnace consumption, of which 60% natural gas and rest electricity. Inputs and outputs renormalized to kt CO2 captured/compressed.

column4: ethylene input is replaced by bio-ethylene produced from bio-ethanol
column19: Assumed that the bio-ethylene is readily available from the market. Furthermore, as bio-ethylene and ethylene are exactly the same chemicals, no modifications to the existing equipment is needed. Therefore, there is no CAPEX involved. However, it is uncertain when this would be a viable option as the market price for bio-ethylene is significantly higher than fossil-based ethylene. We assume that by 2025 bio-ethylene is market competitive.

However, it is uncertain when this would be a viable option as the market price for bio-ethylene is significantly higher than fossil-based ethylene. We assume that by 2025 bio-ethylene is market competitive.

column37: Carbon Trust. Introducing combined heat and power (2010).
column38: The efficiency of the steam turbine is estimated to 42%. The input of steam is 40% of the total steam produced in the boilers. Pressure level is assumption.

column4: The plasma reactor is a chamber in which methane is decomposed with heat produced from electricity.
column13: Costs for the pilot plant are not scalable for this capacity.
column19: Costs for the pilot plant are not scalable for this capacity.
column30: Labanca, A. (2016). Economic analysis of CO2-free hydrogen production from natural gas by plasma pyrolysis.
column37: Calculated from pilot plant data in the report Labanca, A. (2016). Economic Analysis of CO2- free hydrogen production from natural gas by plasma pyrolysis.
column44: Calculated from pilot plant data in the report Labanca, A. (2016). Economic Analysis of CO2- free hydrogen production from natural gas by plasma pyrolysis.
column128: Calculated from pilot plant data in the report Labanca, A. (2016). Economic Analysis of CO2- free hydrogen production from natural gas by plasma pyrolysis.
column225: ESA. (2013). Carbon black pilot facility project.
column226: A pilot project called Seaport Pilot Plant was operated for four years until it was decommissioned in 2018.

column4: The dryers steam generated in an electric boiler.
column12: CE Delft. (2015). Potential for Power-to-Heat in the Netherlands.
column13: The investment costs include the equipment (60 kEUR/kW) and the grid connection (130 kEUR/kW). 7100 kW_output corresponds to 80000 tonne carbon black / year, so investment cost are 16.9 kEUR/tonne carbon black
column30: CE Delft. (2015). Potential for Power-to-Heat in the Netherlands.
column37: Estimation
column38: The amount of pelletized carbon black is calculated taking into account that 1 tonne of carbon black is mixed with 1 tonne of water to provide 2 tonnes of pelletized carbon black
column44: Calculated with the efficiency of the electric boiler (99%) and the energy required to dry the carbon black (2.8 GJ/tonne carbon).

column2: TDM reactor (methane burner, isolated quench chamber, cyclone and filter)
column4: Thermal decomposition of methane (TMD) to produce hydrogen and carbon black. The reactor consists of a methane burner, isolated quench chamber, cyclone and filter.
column13: Investment costs have not been estimated because of the low TRL level of the technology.
column37: Estimation based on an input of 3.3 ton methane per ton fluffy carbon black and a lower heating value of 50 MJ/kg.
column38: Keipi, T., Hankalin, V., Nummelin, J., & Raiko, R. (2015). Techno-economic analysis of fourconcepts for thermal decomposition of methane: Reduction of CO2 emissions in natural gas combustion.

column205: Estimation considering that the combustion of the product gas takes place in the plant. The product gas contains 1 tonne of CO2 and 1.5 tonnes of CH4.
column225: Keipi, T., Hankalin, V., Nummelin, J., & Raiko, R. (2015). Techno-economic analysis of fourconcepts for thermal decomposition of methane: Reduction of CO2 emissions in natural gas combustion.

column13: According to Navigant (2019), Verkenning uitbreiding SDE met industriele opties, an electric cracking furnace would have investment costs of 0.6-4.5 MEUR/MWth. This is for a typical capacity of 5-10 MW and 3600-8760 h/y. For comparison, Semeijn and Schure (2020) use a capex of 2.8-4 MEUR/MW for a 20 MW furnace, which is within the range. VNPI costs include substation, cabling, equipment and project handling for a furnace with 10MWth capacity. Navigant report  does not detail what is included in the figure

column13: According to Navigant (2019), Verkenning uitbreiding SDE met industriele opties, an electric cracking furnace would have investment costs of 0.6-4.5 MEUR/MWth. This is for a typical capacity of 5-10 MW and 3600-8760 h/y. For comparison, Semeijn and Schure (2020) use a capex of 2.8-4 MEUR/MW for a 20 MW furnace, which is within the range. VNPI costs include substation, cabling, equipment and project handling for a furnace with 10MWth capacity. Navigant report  does not detail what is included in the figure

Annexes to the Commission Delegated Regulation determining transitional Union-wide rules for harmonised free allocation of emission allowances pursuant to Article 10a of Directive 2003/87/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council. Cogeneration Observatory and Dissemination Europe (CODE2). (2014). D5.1 - Final Cogeneration Roadmap Member State: The Netherlands. Assuming total emissions of 195,074,000 kgCO2 as registered by NEa (2018). Reference efficiency steam = 85%.
column205: The emission factor for heat  generation by the cogenerator is determined at 48.41 kgCO2/GJth for heat. The emission factor for electricity generation by the cogenerator is determined at 0.38 kgCO2/kWh for electricity. Or, in other words: 56,6 ktCO2/PJ natural gas.

column205: In reality, CO2 is emitted when biomass like spent grains are burned. However, emissions from the burning of biomass are allocated to the point where the biomass is produced and harvested. Next to this, the spent grains are a rest product that are produced either way in the production process of maltings or breweries. Hence, the emissions from the use of biomass by the breweries or maltings are considered to be zero.

Next to this, the spent grains are a rest product that are produced either way in the production process of maltings or breweries. Hence, the emissions from the use of biomass by the breweries or maltings are considered to be zero.
column225: Boots, Wolbers, & Lensink. 2020. Conceptadvies SDE++ 2021 Vergisting van biomassa.

CWT approach  is used by the sector organizations CONCAWE for benchmarking purposes. CWT stands Solomon “CO2 weighted tonne” (CWT) approach. Each process unit presents a standard CWT factor which refers to the net energy consumption and can be translated to CO2 emissions via the formula CO2 emissions = 1,083*0,0295*Unit throughtput*CWT factor.

column205: CO2 emissions were calculated based on the CWT approach, which is used by the sector organizations CONCAWE for benchmarking purposes. Each process unit presents a standard CWT factor which refers to the net energy consumption and can be translated to CO2 emissions via the formula CO2 emissions = 1,083*0,0295*Unit throughtput*CWT factor. For the flexicoking unit the CWT factor is 16,6. More detailed information can be found at source mentioned in this dataset.

column18: Building up the future cost of biofuels (SGAB, 2017)
column19: Extra investment costs are based on adjustments that the FCC unit would need to apply in order to co-process the bio-oil. The production costs of this new feedstock are not included. Refineries may differ in terms of their investment needs and processing capabilities, this is a rough estimate of costs and they would mostly relate to new pipeline and feed nozzle for the pyrolysis bio-oil
column24: Building up the future cost of biofuels (SGAB, 2017)
column25: Extra investment costs are based on adjustments that the FCC unit would need to apply in order to co-process the bio-oil. The production costs of this new feedstock are not included. Refineries may differ in terms of their investment needs and processing capabilities, this is a rough estimate of costs and they would mostly relate to new pipeline and feed nozzle for the pyrolysis bio-oil. The OPEX related to the bio-oil fraction in co-processing is not readily available for estimation, however, the SGAB report based its values on opinion from experts in the field. The basic numbers were used to arrive at a Rough Order of Magnitude (ROM) figure.

column204: CWT approach. Nederlandse lijst van energiedragers en standaard CO2 emissiefactoren, versie januari 2017 (RVO). CWT approach  is used by the sector organizations CONCAWE for benchmarking purposes. CWT stands Solomon “CO2 weighted tonne” (CWT) approach. Each process unit presents a standard CWT factor which refers to the net energy consumption and can be translated to CO2 emissions via the formula CO2 emissions = 1,083*0,0295*Unit throughtput*CWT factor.
column205: emissions due to coke burning during catalyst regeneration. coke consumption based on expert consultation. emission factor for coke based on RVO list (94 kg CO2/GJ). Part of this coke is bio-genic, therefore the fossil emisssions were considered to reduce porportionally to the co-processing %
column225: Lammens, T. (2018). Advanced Biofuels from Fast Pyrolysis Bio-Oil. ETIP Bioenergy Workshop Emerging Technologies, Brussels. Fast pyrolysis oil from pinewood chips co-processing with vacuum gas oil in an FCC unit for second generation fuel production (Pinho, A., 2016)
column226: Technology in demo phase. In Brazil there is a pilot plant of 150 kg/h capacity. A refinery in Sweden will start co-processing in 2021

column19: Investment costs for capture, purification, compression, and transport network connection. Network connection costs based on a unit with capacity of about 0.7 MtCO2 captured/year (Lensink and Schoots, 2021). CO2 purification and compression based on Berghout et al (2015). Lower limit considers that compression equipment is already present (only network connection is needed). Mid range costs are based on Berghout et al. (deflated from 2012 to 2020 EUR based on European HICP index), combined with compression/network costs from Lensink and Schoots 2021. Upper limit based on Danish Energy Agency/Energinet (2021a) considering only investments for CO2 compression & dehydration. Transport and storage equipment is excluded.

column25: 3% of investment costs for fixed O&M costs. Transport and storage costs are excluded from this value. Storage costs assume Porthos tarriff, transportation assuming pipeline access. 8000 hours assumed.

column2: Conventional production process (cracking furnaces, butadiene and MTBE units, gasoline and benzene systems)
column4: Thermal conversion of organic feedstock to light olefins and aromatics. This includes cracking, cracked gas compression and distillation sections for products recovery and the downstream processes for butadiene, MTBE, pyrolysis gasoline and benzene production.
column37: Interview with the company
column38: Based on the input of naphtha (4000 kt) and output of ethylene (1150 kt) in 2018.
column44: Interview with the company
column45: The steam imported from the Swentibold power plant is superheated high-pressure steam (140 bar, 525°C). The total steam import in 2018 was around 7 PJ.
column51: Interview with the company
column52: Methanol is used in the MTBE production unit. The process ratio is around 0.47 kt methanol/ MTBE produced.
column58: Interview with the company
column59: Based on the total electricity consumption in 2018, which was 1 PJ for all the units combined.
column122: The steam cracking process produces different products. Ethylene was chosen as main output for simplicity. Normally, the benchmark of this process groups the output as high value chemicals (HVC), which includes: hydrogen, acetylene, ethylene, propylene, butadiene and benzene. The total HVC production from SABIC in 2018 was 2259 kt.
column128: Interview with the company. Boulamanti A, & Moya JA. (2017b). Energy efficiency and GHG emissions: Prospective scenarios for the Chemical and Petrochemical Industry. https://doi.org/10.2760/630308.
column129: In 2018, SABIC Geleen produced around 680 kt of propylene. This  value was used to calculate the ratio kt propylene/kt ethylene. The lower limit relates to a naphtha cracker and was extracted from Boulamanti A. and Moya J.A. (2017).
column135: Interview with the company. Boulamanti A, & Moya JA. (2017b). Energy efficiency and GHG emissions: Prospective scenarios for the Chemical and Petrochemical Industry. https://doi.org/10.2760/630308.
column136: In 2018, SABIC Geleen produced around 35 kt of hydrogen. This value was used to calculate the average ratio kt hydrogen/kt ethylene. Hydrogen is exported to other facilities in the Chemelot campus. The lower limit relates to a naphtha cracker and was extracted from Boulamant and Moya (2017).
column142: Interview with the company
column143: In 2018, SABIC Geleen produced around 4 kt of acetylene and this value was used for determining the average ratio kt acetylene/kt ethylene.
column149: Interview with the company. Boulamanti A, & Moya JA. (2017b). Energy efficiency and GHG emissions: Prospective scenarios for the Chemical and Petrochemical Industry. https://doi.org/10.2760/630308.
column150: In 2018, SABIC Geleen produced around 110 kt of butadiene. This value was used to calculate the average ratio kt butadiene/kt ethylene. The upper limit was extracted Boulamanti and Moya (2017).
column157: The pyrolysis gasoline is partially used as feedstock for the benzene extraction unit (around 1020 kt In 2018). SABIC Geleen produced around 110 kt of hydrogen and this value was used to determine the average ratio kt pyrolysis gasoline/kt ethylene.
column178: This oil is used as feedstock for the carbon black industry.
column185: Steam (around 18 bar)  sourced from compressors which is exported to other facilities in Chemelot.
column192: The steam cracking reaction produces a methane-rich gas which is used to provide the needed heat for the furnaces. A small fraction of this fuel gas is exported to USG and used as fuel in boilers. In 2018 the value of residual gas exported was 44 kt. An average LHV of 50,24 GJ/t was used,  based on information from the Milieujaarverslag 2015 Site Chemelot (2015).
column204: Milieujaarverslag 2015 Site Chemelot (2015).Ren, T., Patel, M., & Blok, K. (2006). Olefins from conventional and heavy feedstocks: Energy use in steam cracking and alternative processes. Energy. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.energy.2005.04.001
column205: Direct  emissions calculated based on total site's energy consumption. The emission factor for fuel gas (54.2 kg CO2/GJ) was extracted from Milieujaarverslag 2015 Site Chemelot (2015). The lower and upper values were based on Ren et al. (2006).
column226: Proven technology already widely commercially available. Similar technology for steam cracking is used in other sites in The Netherlands (Dow Terneuzen and Shell Moerdijk).

column2: Full electrification of cracking furnaces, butadiene and MTBE units and gasoline and benzene systems.

column38: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
column45: The steam imported from the Swentibold power plant is superheated high-pressure steam (140 bar, 525°C). The total steam import in 2018 was around 7 PJ. It was assumed that full electrification of furnaces would not change the steam import, since it was considered that the superheating of the steam produced in the furnaces would continue to happen via electrical heating. For details see the MIDDEN report.
column52: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
column59: The electricity consumption encompasses both current electricty demand and the additional demand for electrical cracking. For the electrity demand of the furnaces, a thermal efficiency of 98,5% is considered (93,5% was considered for the conventional furnaces). The naphtha pre-heating and the steam super-heating are considered to be done via electrical heating, therefore, no changes in the steam flows were considered.
column122: The steam cracking process produces different products. Ethylene was chosen as main output for simplicity. Normally, the benchmark of this process groups the output as high value chemicals (HVC), which includes: hydrogen, acetylene, ethylene, propylene, butadiene and benzene. The total HVC production from SABIC in 2018 was 2259 kt.

column205: Direct  emissions from the cracking furnaces are avoided. Only the emissions due to flaring are assumed to remain. The flaring emissions were around 8 kt in 2018. For full assessment of the CO2 emissions, the source of electricity should also  be taken into account.
column225: IEA (2020). ETP Clean Energy Technology Guide.
column226: Electric  furnaces are already commonly used in steel production and in glass production. The technology offers the possibility to be adapted to other high-temperature heat processes that are currently difficult to electrify, such as cracking furnaces from steam crackers.

column2: Electric boilers supply steam to cracking furnaces, butadiene and MTBE units and gasoline and benzene systems.
column4: The current steam import is considered to be substituted by steam from electrical boilers.
column12: Berenschot (2017). Electrification in the Dutch process industry. In-depth study of promising transition pathways and innovation opportunities for electrification in the Dutch process industry.
column13: The investment costs are based on a 70 MWe input boiler. The original values were 150-190 kEUR2017/MWe. The costs were adjusted using a scaling factor of 0.7  and a capacity of 222 MWe, based on the steam demand. The figures include equipment and electrical connection costs. The latter may vary significantly depending on the site. Therefore, the estimated figure might not represent the actual situation for the SABIC Geleen site.

column45: The steam import is reduced because the compressors no longer need steam to run. It was considered that the available steam from the furnaces is used on site to meet the demand of the other downstream units, resulting in around 2,4 PJ/yr of imported steam. The quality of this steam is yet undefined because each downstream process uses a different steam level. Most likely it would be high pressure steam. More details about this configuration can be found in the MIDDEN+ report.
column52: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
column59: The electricity consumption includes both the current electricity demand and the additional demand of electrical compressors. For the compressors an efficiency of 90% was assumed.
column122: The steam cracking process produces different products. Ethylene was chosen as main output for simplicity. Normally, the benchmark of this process groups the output as high value chemicals (HVC), which includes: hydrogen, acetylene, ethylene, propylene, butadiene and benzene. The total HVC production from SABIC in 2018 was 2259 kt.

column185: The steam cracking reaction produces a methane-rich gas which is used to provide the needed heat for the furnaces. A small fraction of this fuel gas is exported to USG and used as fuel in boilers. In 2018 the value of residual gas exported was 44 kt. An average LHV of 50,24 GJ/t was used,  based on information from the Milieujaarverslag 2015 Site Chemelot (2015). With electrical compressors in place, no changes in the fuel gas consumption within SABIC are expected.
column192: Same material yields as the conventional process were assumed
column204: Milieujaarverslag 2015 Site Chemelot (2015).Ren, T., Patel, M., & Blok, K. (2006). Olefins from conventional and heavy feedstocks: Energy use in steam cracking and alternative processes. Energy. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.energy.2005.04.001
column205: Direct  emissions are the same as the conventional case because currently SABIC imports steam from Swentibold power plant. However, the scope 2 emissions could be reduced depending on the grid's emission factor.
column226: Electrical compressors are proven technology, already widely commercially available. However, it is not common to have electrical compressors in steam cracking facilities instead of steam-driven compressors.

column45: For this configuration, it was assumed that the steam superheating was no longer done via electrical heating. Therefore, the heat delivered by the furnaces to the downstream units is reduced and the external demand increases by around 0,8 PJ/yr compared to the consumption in 2018 (7 PJ). More details about this configuration can be found in the MIDDEN+ report. The steam quality is uncertain. Medium pressure steam was assumed.
column52: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
column59: The electricity consumption encompasses both current electricty demand and the additional demand for electrical cracking. For the electrity demand of the furnaces, a thermal efficiency of 98,5% is considered (93,5% was considered for the conventional furnaces).  For the electricity demand of the compressors, a thermal efficiency of 90% is assumed.
column122: The steam cracking process produces different products. Ethylene was chosen as main output for simplicity. Normally, the benchmark of this process groups the output as high value chemicals (HVC), which includes: hydrogen, acetylene, ethylene, propylene, butadiene and benzene. The total HVC production from SABIC in 2018 was 2259 kt.

column205: Direct  emissions from the cracking furnaces are avoided. Only the emissions due to flaring are assumed to remain. The flaring emissions were around 8 kt in 2018. For full assessment of the CO2 emissions, the source of electricity should also  be taken into account.
column225: IEA (2020). ETP Clean Energy Technology Guide.
column226: Electric  furnaces are already commonly used in steel production and in glass production. The technology offers the possibility to be adapted to other high-temperature heat processes that are currently difficult to electrify, such as cracking furnaces from steam crackers. Electrical compressors are proven technology already widely commercially available. Therefore, the limitation exists mainly in the development of electrical cracking.

column13: The investment is based on the SDE++ subsidy advice (Lensink, 2020) for a large-scale electric boiler. It includes direct costs (boiler, superheater, pump systems, on-site electricity infrastructure, piping, measuring equipment, civil works, scaffolding and cranes) and indirect costs (engineering, supervision), but it does not include unforeseen costs and it is assumed that an existing grid connection can be used. The lower limit is based on the investment for a 15 MWth electric boiler, including equipment costs (85%) and installation costs (15%) (DEA/Energinet, 2020a). The upper value is based on the investment for a 1-5 MW electric boiler and includes grid connection fees (DEA/Energinet, 2020b). In some cases, the required investments for a grid connection can be higher (Jansen, e.a. 2019).
column24: Lensink, S. (2020), Eindadvies Basisbedragen SDE++ 2020, Den Haag: PBL.. Electrification of industry. Facilitating the integration of offshore wind with Power-to-Heat in industry, Akzo Nobel, Deltalinqs, Shell & TenneT, DNV GL, 2018..Technology Data Industrial process heat and CC, Danish Energy Agency/Energinet, 2020a.
column25: We assume fixed operation and maintenance costs equal to 2% of the equipment costs (DNV GL, 2018). We assume that equipment costs make up 85% of the investment (DEA/Energinet, 2020a). As in Lensink (2020), we do not assume variable operating and maintenance costs. The O&M costs exclude costs for materials and energy. Any levies, taxes or subsidies (which may be linked to products, raw materials and emissions) are not included. Connection tariffs, supply and metering fees, costs for contracted capacity and transport tariffs are not included.
column30: Lensink, S. (2020), Eindadvies Basisbedragen SDE++ 2020, Den Haag: PBL.. Electrification of industry. Transport and storage equipment is excluded.

column2: Add-on CO2 capture & compression (high concentration) for gaseous transport
column4: Capture and compression of high-concentration CO2 streams (>95%vol) based on inherent separation in industrial processes, for gaseous transport (compressed to ~35 bar) (100% capture rate). Assumes that only compression and network connection are needed, capture is inherent to the process. Most often used in combination with pipeline transport.
column12: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL. Berghout, N. et al. (2015). Techno-economic performance and spatial footprint of infrastructure configurations for large scale CO2 capture in industrial zones: A case study for the Rotterdam Botlek area. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control 39: 256-284.
column13: CAPEX for capture, purification, compression, and transport network connection. Network connection costs based on a unit with capacity of about 0.7 MtCO2 captured/year (Lensink 2021). CO2 purification and compression based on Berghout et al (2015). Lower limit considers that compression equipment is already present (only network connection is needed). Mid range costs are based on Berghout et al. (deflated from 2012 to 2020 EUR based on European HICP index), combined with compression/network costs from Lensink 2021. Upper limit based on Danish Energy Agency (2021) post-combustion capture for small CHP, considering only invesments for CO2 compression & dehydration. Transport and storage equipment is excluded (see Lensink 2021 Chapter 17 for cost estimates).
column24: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL.
column25: 3% of CAPEX for fixed O&M costs. Transport and storage costs are excluded from this value.
column30: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL. Berghout, N. et al. (2015). Techno-economic performance and spatial footprint of infrastructure configurations for large scale CO2 capture in industrial zones: A case study for the Rotterdam Botlek area. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control 39: 256-284. Husebye, J., Brunsvold, A., Roussanaly, S., & Zhang, X. (2012). Techno economic evaluation of amine based CO2 capture: impact of CO2 concentration and steam supply.
column37: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL. Danish Energy Agency/Energinet, 2020a, Technology Data Industrial process heat and CC. Berghout, N. et al. (2015). Techno-economic performance and spatial footprint of infrastructure configurations for large scale CO2 capture in industrial zones: A case study for the Rotterdam Botlek area. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control 39: 256-284.
column38: See p 173 of Lensink (2021). 125 kWh/tCO2 for compression.  Upper limit based on Berghout et al. (2015), lower limit based on Danish Energy Agency (2021).
column122: Note that CO2 captured is CO2 that has been captured and compressed to the appropriate level for transport.
column205: Capture rate for inherent separation is 100%, based on the input gas stream. Note that avoided emissions may be lower depending on the utilities that provide the necessary electricity.
column225: Global CCS Institute (2021). Technology Readiness and Costs of CCS.
column226: Inherent separation already occurs as part of the industrial process. CO2 compression is a well-known, commercially mature technique.

column2: Add-on CO2 capture & compression (high concentration) for liquefied transport
column4: Capture and compression of high-concentration CO2 streams (>95%vol) based on inherent separation in industrial processes, for liquefied transport (compressed to ~110 bar) (100% capture rate). Assumes that only compression/liquefaction and network connection are needed, capture is inherent to the process. Most often used in combination with transport by truck or ship.
column12: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL.
column13: CAPEX for capture, purification, compression, and liquefaction.  Costs based on a unit with capacity of about 0.7 MtCO2 captured/year. Main value based on a new installation, upper limit based on a retrofit at an existing site. Transport and storage equipment is excluded (see Lensink 2021 Chapter 17 for cost estimates).
column24: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL.
column25: 3% of CAPEX for fixed O&M costs. Transport and storage costs are excluded from this value.
column30: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL. Berghout, N. et al. (2015). Techno-economic performance and spatial footprint of infrastructure configurations for large scale CO2 capture in industrial zones: A case study for the Rotterdam Botlek area. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control 39: 256-284. Husebye, J., Brunsvold, A., Roussanaly, S., & Zhang, X. (2012). Techno economic evaluation of amine based CO2 capture: impact of CO2 concentration and steam supply.
column37: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL. Danish Energy Agency/Energinet, 2020a, Technology Data Industrial process heat and CC. Berghout, N. et al. (2015). Techno-economic performance and spatial footprint of infrastructure configurations for large scale CO2 capture in industrial zones: A case study for the Rotterdam Botlek area. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control 39: 256-284.
column38: See p 173 of Lensink (2021). 162 kWh/tCO2 for liquefaction.  Upper limit based on Berghout et al. (2015), lower limit based on Danish Energy Agency (2021).
column122: Note that CO2 captured is CO2 that has been captured and compressed to the appropriate level for transport.
column205: Capture rate for inherent separation is 100%, based on the input gas stream. Note that avoided emissions may be lower depending on the utilities that provide the necessary electricity.
column225: Global CCS Institute (2021). Technology Readiness and Costs of CCS.
column226: Inherent separation already occurs as part of the industrial process. CO2 compression is a well-known, commercially mature technique.
